content: Hey @WG-traits, meeting in 10 minutes. Please start adding thoughts and notes into the agenda hackmd!
It feels like it's been a busy week or two, so there ought to be some "notable events" to log:)
I wonder btw

we have this document with our sprint goals, I feel like it might be nice to "slot" ongoing work into there, so that we're just -- week by week -- accumultaing a log of what we did? sigh, so many ways I might like to track things :)
I would say that would be nice. But this week has been so busy that I can't keep up with that right now
heh yeah, I was mostly thinking 'instead of the older system'
but it has indeed been really busy!
I think it could be good every few days to just update the hackmd with the status of each
@WG-traits meeting time
Let's start with notable events and updates and such
So, it's been a very busy week
So, shoutout to all the new people around :)
Starting last Tuesday, 11 PRs have been merged
and there are another 11 open right now
holy cow

Jack Huey said:

I think it could be good every few days to just update the hackmd with the status of each

yep, although it also makes sense to do this just in the issues, so...idk
Yeah, I think updating the sprint hackmd every so often keep us on track in the longer term
The quality of the issues has gone up, which is surprising given how busy things were
The descriptions, I mean
Agreed
I think it definitely helps to think about things in small chunks
Also, I love to see the row of issues with assignees next to them
Yeah, so anybody have anything they want to announce or share what they're working on
I'm looking over the wg-traits sprint doc
maybe we can briefly hit on each thing?
I've got one: tests for impl Trait are green!
For me, still working on rustc integration. It's getting close™

nikomatsakis said:

maybe we can briefly hit on each thing?

sounds good
rustc integration
so I did a prelim review
there were a few open questions, right, like how much do we want to get the work on extending TypeName landed first?
Hmm
so, I would say that even if we land any TypeName changes
I don't know if it's worth using them initially
Since, unless we get full support
for things like FnDefs/FnPtrs/etc.
one obvious blocker is figuring out the crates.io release story
but maybe the answer is that everything else can wait and be patched up in follow-up PRs
which is an agenda item
ok, let's discuss it then?
I'm of the mind that once we get the rustc PR ready, we should do a chalk release
I'm hesitant to say earlier, because we might need to make smaller adjustments
but...probably not
I tend to think we should start to adopt a kind of "release schedule"
I think I've caught things
but maybe we can discuss that later?
let's do the other status updates
Plan for what const integration looks like (tracking issue)
Honestly, I think our release schedule should be "when we get something new"
have a pending PR, #393
So, we had that meeting
and we had the design meeting
And the wg-traits issue is still up
I commented
I think one thing to talk about is what kind of documentation updates are needed there, too
We can close it when we get meeting notes up :)
I'm a bit behind on them

nikomatsakis said:

I think one thing to talk about is what kind of documentation updates are needed there, too

documentation where

on writing up meeting notes? I'm not sure how much energy is worth investing into it, versus (say) trying to write docs, given that an impl exists etc. At least I wouldn't try to cover too many details
I am imagining the chalk book
By meeting notes, I just mean the regular meeting minutes
(One thing that @Areredify mentioned also was that there might be some opportunities for code refactoring and cleanup, also.)
Yeah, it would be good to make sure we update the chalk book
I think a chalk book has a much higher payoff as a time investment
Than meeting notes
A question: for chalk book updates, do we want to "block" big PRs like this on chalk book updates too?
I lean more towards "no"
I lean towards no, but I do think we need to not neglect it too much
I’d like to put a plug in for a chalk book.. that’s exactly what I thought of when I saw the const PR
I would be game to put some more time into it
but I also imagine it could be somewhat helpful in making sure we actually get docs
note that we do have a chalk book
though it needs more work :)
ah, for continuing to update then :)
but just some comments suggested like it doesn't exist yet
(not saying it should block PRs, just that I think it’s important)
(https://rust-lang.github.io/chalk/book/)
One thing I think we could do
Okay, if we don't block PRs, I think we should be diligent of at least opening followup issues for specific documentation
I guess I think putting more energy just into the table of contents is good
like, even just having chapters that point to bits of rustdoc and PRs
Creating an issue seems like a good way to not forget it
is potentially quite helpful
(both for readers and to track work that needs to be done)
I see, that makes sense
Hmm
but for now I say we make an issue :P
I wonder if it is worth blocking big PRs on that
i.e. adding a link to the PR in the table of contents
I think it may be
and then also filing a followup issue for full docs
ok, next item?
ps I'm trying to take some notes in the sprints doc
Then, we can (maybe) make a tracking issue to collate all the chalk book doc issues
Move towards alignment of rustc and chalk types, and towards extracting a shared library
ok so --
we had a number of PRs land here
and we've got some in progress, such as the work on type-name
basically all the chalk refactoring issues I had created are closed
so, rustc side of things :)
I created a spreadsheet comparing rustc / chalk names
and I think there's a bit of bikeshedding to be done in #wg-traits > names of things
and yeah, I guess the next step is probably to open up some rustc refactoring issues and try to leave some notes on those
/me thinks about Region vs. Lifetime
as well as finishing up the TypeName work that is in progress in chalk#368 and elsewhere
Agreed
I think a good concrete goal to be working towards, as an aside
is getting things sufficiently lined up that
/me is extremely displeased that map is called Fold
the rustc-chalk integration can use Ty<'tcx> as Interner::InternedType
this is not to say that they have to share the same details
but that they should be cleanly mappable
the main blockers there are I think having to do with details of binding
so that is probably what I would focus on first and foremost
yeah, we can go into details elsewhere
next item?
but I think the biggest "blockers" to 1:1 mapping
is Params, and Region differences
basic support for impl Trait
great work @detrumi
getting close :)
not sure if there's much else to say about that
Yes, hopefully just only one rebase left (and some cleanup)
progress towards removing leak check in rustc
I have a pending PR
I missed that
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/70950
This PR aligns the NLL region checker with the older, lexical region checker
will have to look later
However, it's not quite enough to remove the leak check, because there are some back-compat issues we have to work through
progress though :)
I think details are probably out of scope for this moment, but I plan to do a bit of exploration there, and if someone is interested in it I'd be happy to deep dive some later
Yes
Time check, 23 minutes in
this is taking some time :) but it seems useful
yes
let's move to next item quick though!
exploration and research
recursive solver
so @Florian Diebold has a pending PR and would like to land it
I reviewed a lot of it, didn't quite finish, but I'm amenable once we patch up the tests just a bit (haven't checked if they left any comments)
I do think we should talk about breaking up chalk-solve, or at least documenting its internal structure
e.g. notable because this solver lives in chalk-solve
I'm good with landing it once tests pass, as long as we don't remove anything related to the existing solver
and I think it's kind of got a few logical "strata" within one crate now
and I think it'd be useful to at least document those, and maybe hard separate them by crate
Yes, landing things quickly and iterating seems to work well for chalk atm
(butI think that can all come later)
Yes, when we land let's file some followup issues for a couple things:
• Breaking up into separate crates
• Documentation
• Comparison between that and slg
Anything else?
Maybe followup design questions too
do you mean "issues"?
yes
ok, seems good
moving on
explore converting semantic-to-syntactic equality
no progress I think?
yeah
create a chalk file from any given program
I saw some discussion here?
this has been picked up :)
who is working on it?
@David Ross and I think @Super Tuple
I guess the discussion was in #wg-traits > .chalk file writer
Indeed
moving on
increase Chalk performance (very open-ended)
No work
just had some discussion with @Zahari Dichev
I think they want to work on this in a bit
add more to Chalk book
we've already somewhat discussed this
But, I don't think we've landed anything new
Anything else?
Not from my side
Okay
That's it, I think
time check 30 minutes
let's move on?
So, we've already discussed release?
Are there concrete next steps for that?
I'm not sure
I guess we can talk elsewhere what the release process is going to be
frequency-wise though
do we want to try to aim for weekly and/or even "big" change
I don't think we need to setup a release train or anything
Agreed
but I've definitely found it kind of annoying managing releases in the past
I guess I just think we want to make the process very easy
I said it should be "regular" earlier, but I think what I meant is more like "let's streamline the process so we can do it easily"
Any way we can just have releases based on github tags?
I guess it's plausible to create a github action or something
that triggers off from a new tag?
We do that at work for some of the things we work on and it works fantastically
Not sure if anybody's tried to do that before
i.e., to do a cargo publish
another thing to discuss: do we want release notes etc
yep
I think ... "probably not"
um
probably?
but we should pay some attention to our commit messages
heh :)
I'm not opposed, but that's part of the "make things easy" ...
When you make a tag on github it's easy to add notes
I don't think we need to add notes to crates.io though
well, that requires typing etc
and more importantly knowing what to type
which requires a bit of research into what's landed, etc
Mmm
If you're making a release, you should know why you're releasing though?
you might know one reason
there are conventions people sometimes follow, so tha the release notes can be easily extracted from the git logs
I think we should always put something
but then we'd have to learn that..
Even if it's "something and other stuff"
anyway, I'm not really arguing against notes, but I also think that for a time
we're going to be publishing a lot of releases like 0.1, 0.2, 0.3
and effectively people are going to wind up looking at git logs to kind of tell what's going on anyway
otoh if we create a release note file
fair enough
maybe we just make it part of the PR to add to that file..
Starting with one-liners, like the "something and other stuff", seems light-weight enough to start off with
family friendly git logs, got it
..if it seems noteworthy :)

nikomatsakis said:

maybe we just make it part of the PR to add to that file..

I like this

detrumi said:

Starting with one-liners, like the "something and other stuff", seems light-weight enough to start off with

this is also ok, yes, but I think there'll be a desire to "do it right"
it's a little bit more upkeep
yeah, I'd be ok with a RELEASES.md
it should have a section at the top for "master" that we add to
a bit of merge work but that's ok
I'm also okay with "let's start with the one-liners and see how things goes"
So, action plan:
let's start with a RELEASES.md
and try it out for a few releases
or a couple months
https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/ ?
and reevaluate if things seem to be too much...work
time check, 40 minutes
seems good.
if this is good, for everyone, let's move on
we shouldl also just write down the steps to issue a release (e.g., bump cargo.toml numbers, cargo publish, etc)
(also, hi, I'm a potential new contributor once this semester finishes up)
Okay, someone should make a PR for adding CHANGELOG and a space in the chalk book for release info
Talking about more contributors
volunteers?
We need more sprint issues
I can volunteer
If we have time, we'll talk about sprint issues at the end. Otherwise, we'll talk async
Where should "builtin" types go? chalk-ir or chalk-rust-ir?
So, I think this one was mostly for me
But I'm somewhat convinced now that chalk-ir is the right place
me too :)
(these are types like bool, ints, floats, etc.)
moving on...
rustc integration
so, we've talked a bit about this before
so probably don't need much
But I'm think we might want to schedule a design meeting to specifically talk about this?
Or part of one
hmm
I think things are still moving atm
I did want to ask @nikomatsakis though, you were doing some work regarding changing LifetimeEq to Outlives, right?
I don't know that we need a design meeting exactly, but I do think it'd there's some kind of sync we want
i.e., we're going to land something pretty imperfect, and we want to have a good idea of what work still needs to be done
that we can use to drive follow-up work
and hmm yeah the story around regions are a big item on that list
/me tries to remember what work he was doing :P
I did have a branch that changed LifetimeEq to outlives, yes
Well, right now, what we're going to land doesn't handle *Outlives at all
right, and I'm ok with that
Right
but there does seem to be some kind of design meeting waiting around there
Right, which is somewhat why I thought I would bring it up
what I was trying to do in my branch, overall, was to change how chalk handled "higher-ranked" region constraints
I looked at it briefly, but it's been a while
but I'm not sure how much it's worth digging into that here ;) that's the issue I was alluding to when I said I'd be happy to "deep dive" later when talking about leak check removal, also
in any case, that could definitely be a design meeting or 3 :)
still, just extracting out that one part -- the outlives part -- might be worth doing
Okay, then let's plan for a design meeting around lifetime/region handling async
So Subtype
do you want to try and do a walk over the rustc integration PR?
and compile that list?
I could see that being useful
e.g., getting on zoom or something and scrolling together and taking notes
yes
(and of course anyone who wants could join us)
let's discuss that in the rustc integration stream
11 minutes left
seems good
The last agenda item I put down was to briefly discuss "old" PRs
i.e. PRs that haven't been active
yeah
and deciding what the state of them
the first one (https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/pull/230)
is this superseded by the impl Trait work
Interesting, didn't know there was already work on Reveal
I think so
forgot about that PR, sorry @Sunjay Varma =)
Reveal might still be useful
But I think there were still questions on the overrides part, looking at the PR
I mean, maybe someone(s) might want to look through it and see if there's anything work splitting out
but I think we should close this as is?
I just don't know much about what the motivation for the PR was
oh this was working towards specialization
right, right
interesting
I think we should probably just close it
okay
it's not worth actively rebasing, we should log it for when we pick specializaiton back up perhaps
The next one (https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/pull/277)
Was my first PR
(I think my first)
one of 'em, anyway
I don't think it was your first
I also think we should probably close this :)
But, I think this is "blocked" on some kind of benchmarking
I agree
It's a potentially valid question in the future
but not super helpful right now
yes
but we might also wind up adopting recursive solver and removing SLG or various other things
seems like the profiling data will bring us back here if it's important
right
last one: https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/pull/331
oh dear
@Florian Diebold's
I've been meaning to understand what this is about :)
so, I'll start by saying that I think @Zahari Dichev is going to investigate this a bit
although for some reason I thought this was a long PR
it's like 3 lines lol
no, it's rather short
/me embarassed
but 3 impactful lines :)
but I think the test in the comment doesn't pass with these changes
But passes on master
But the test added doesn't pass on master
I think I stand by my comment though, that I'm not sure we should be suggesting a substitution if we flounder
but does with the change

A commit that references it explains it a bit:

I found one source of nondeterminism (rust-lang/chalk#331), but there are still
other cases remaining.
that commit comes from rust-analyzer?
this still seems worth landing to me

nikomatsakis said:

I think I stand by my comment though, that I'm not sure we should be suggesting a substitution if we flounder

I was thinking about this
or certainly still relevant
yeah
I'm not sure how useful it is to have any suggestion on ambiguous
ever
the motivation for suggestions
was that rustc has some quirky behavior
that we will likely have to be able to emulate for back-compat reasons
where it sometimes makes semi-arbitrary decisions on ambiguity
you can actually see some lines referring to this in the recursive solver, we never added back that kind of logic fully to SLG I think
interesting
in particular I'm sure we'll run into this, but it's a problem I'd like to have
and I think for now we should probably just ignore suggestions by and large
that is, I think it's ok to give less
As far as this PR though, let's see if both the tests pass
if so, I think it's fine to land
If you'd like to see some more notes on rustc's behavior, and how wacky it can be, see #41756 =)
but if not, there's a deeper issue that I've had a hunch about
(time check: 1:01 :)
Alright, that's it for the meeting
wow, that was productive
ah, something not on our list: introduce tracing into chalk (cc @David Barsky)
(I started a new job, i'm really sorry! but i can push the tracing-tree to crates.io as an alpha?)
s/job/team
we skipped right over that alongside the performance improvements
if you push the tracing-tree crate
I'll get the tracing PR finished up :)
cool, okay :)
i feel bad because I'm not entirely sure _what_ should be correctly instrumented.
anyways, i'll push it in a second.
tbh your PR is basically good to land
a bit of cleanup, but a good start
@nikomatsakis I updated the recursive solver PR, btw
@Florian Diebold Great. I'll skim the details of the solver now.
